d16afa0ae7c.name: Backchannel
d16afa0ae7c.shortDescription: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales.

paragraphs.name: a3a9
paragraphs.text: Here’s how it works: our staffers recommend favorites — just in time for you to use the gift certificates you got for the holidays — and tell you why the book is worth reading. And then we provide proof: a juicy excerpt from every one we recommend. It’s just the thing to help divert you from the fact that 2017 may be even worse than this year.

When I first began writing about technology, a modest shelf could actually hold pretty much all the volumes that we now recognized as “tech books” — business-oriented tomes about tech companies, geeky explorations of hardware or software milestones, celebratory 0r scary projections of what our current products will morph to, and one more biography of Steve Jobs. Now they tumble out like doughnuts on a conveyor belt, as zillions of writers covering the field realize that to make a statement they have to go really longform.
paragraphs.name: 489f
489f

Now they tumble out like doughnuts on a conveyor belt, as zillions of writers covering the field realize that to make a statement they have to go really longform.

paragraphs.text: Death’s End is amazing. The Three Body Problem and The Dark Forest were merely “good” books compared to this masterpiece. Easily the best book I read this year, and I read a lot.

ec7a279dae39.title: This is a very nice reading list.

paragraphs.text: This is a very nice reading list. Technology is becoming more intertwined in our lives and is becoming essential to understand in order to make it in today’s world. Here is my reading list. Many of the books aren’t related to technology but they were really great reads and many of the biographies of comedians and presidents were influenced by my work…
